revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2018}} '''Adiadochokinesia''' is a [[dyskinesia]] consisting of inability to perform the rapid alternating movements of [[diadochokinesia]]. Called also ''adiadochocinesia'', ''adiadochokinesis'', and ''adiadokokinesia''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095351272|title=Adiadochokinesia - Oxford Reference|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
Compare with [[dysdiadochokinesia]], which is an impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements.
== References == {{Reflist}} * Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary, 21ed. 2009
[[Category:Medical terminology]] [[Category:Symptoms and signs: Nervous system]]

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup|date=June 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2013}} }} {{Infobox military person |name=Agim Ramadani |birth_date= 3 May 1963 |birth_place=[[Žegra]], [[Gnjilane]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] |death_date= 11 April 1999 |death_place= [[Košare]], [[FR Yugoslavia]] |image= Permendorja Agim Ramadani.JPG |image_size = 190px |caption= Monument of Agim Ramadani |allegiance= |serviceyears= |rank=[[Commander]] |commands=[[File:UCK KLA.png|22px]] [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] |unit=138 Brigade |battles=[[Kosovo War]]
[[Battle of Košare]] |laterwork= |awards=[[Hero of Kosovo]] (posthumously){{cite web|url=http://kryeministri-ks.net/?page=2,9,3479}} |enteredservice= }} '''Agim Ramadani''' (3 May 1963 – 11 April 1999) was a commander of the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] (KLA), an ethnic Albanian paramilitary organization that sought the independence of Kosovo from Serbia. He was killed in action. ==Biography== Agim Ramadani{{ref label|names|a|}} was born in the village of [[Žegra]] ({{lang-sq|Zhegër}}) in the municipality of [[Gnjilane]] ({{lang|sq|Gjilan}}) in [[AP Kosovo]]. He studied at the higher technical school in Gnjilane in 1980, and the Military Academy for communications in [[Zagreb]], [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|SR Croatia]]. Poetry and painting were his passions during high school. His poetry was published in literary magazines, whereas painting exhibitions were organized in Croatia, where he worked as a JNA officer, and in Switzerland, where lived after the [[Croatian War]] broke out. In 1998 Ramadani accepted honorary membership at the European Academy of Arts. In 1998, Ramadani left Switzerland, where his wife and three children (two sons and a daughter[http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts21/AH1999_1.html albanian history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402131523/http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts21/AH1999_1.html |date=2015-04-02 }}) lived, and joined the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] (KLA).[http://www.lajmeonline.net/en/to-the-ta-nderojne-Agim-ramadanin/ Agim Ramadani] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402101800/http://www.lajmeonline.net/en/to-the-ta-nderojne-Agim-ramadanin/ |date=2015-04-02 }} He fell at the [[Battle of Košare]]. ==Legacy== Agim is regarded an Albanian hero.{{citation|accessdate=2013-11-09 |url=http://news.albanianscreen.tv/pages/news_detail/50923/ENG |publisher=AS TV |title=The exhibit of a hero, Berisha: Agim Ramadani, an eminent patriot |date=November 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110060854/http://news.albanianscreen.tv/pages/news_detail/50923/ENG |archivedate=November 10, 2013 }} A main street in [[Pristina]] is named after him.{{citation|url=http://kk.rks-gov.net/prishtina/News/Te-premten-mbyllet-pjeserisht-per-qarkullim-rruga-.aspx|accessdate=2013-10-07|language=Albanian|publisher=Municipality of Prishtina|date=2013-09-25|title=Të premten mbyllet pjesërisht për qarkullim rruga "Agim Ramadani"|trans-title="Agim Ramadani" street will be partly closed for circulation on Friday}} ==Notes== {| style="margin-left:13px; line-height:150%" |align="right" valign="top"|a.   |{{note|names}}[[Albanian language|Albanian spelling]]: ''Agim Ramadani'', {{lang-sr-cyr|Агим Рамадани}}. |- |align="right" valign="top"|b.   |{{note|status}}{{Kosovo-note}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|author1=John Oppenheim|author2=Willem-Jan van der Wolf|author3=Global Law Association|title=Global war crimes tribunal collection|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t1c6AQAAIAAJ|year=|publisher=Global Law Association}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ramadani, Agim}} [[Category:Heroes of Kosovo]] [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Albanian writers]] [[Category:Albanian nationalists in Kosovo]] [[Category:Kosovo Albanians]] [[Category:Kosovo Liberation Army]] [[Category:People from Gjilan]] [[Category:Albanian-language writers]] [[Category:Albanian male writers]] [[Category:Albanian expatriates in Switzerland]] [[Category:20th-century Albanian military personnel]] [[Category:Yugoslav people of Albanian descent]] [[Category:Albanian artists]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]] [[Category:Independence activists]]

The '''Aimol''' are one of the Old Kuki peoples of [[Manipur]] and [[Assam]] in [[India]]. They are one of the [[Adivasi|Scheduled tribes]]. They speak the [[Aimol language]] which is a [[Tibeto-Burman]] language.
They Aimol number about 5000. They practice [[slash-and-burn]] agriculture and are primarily Christian.
==Sources== *http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=aim
[[Category:Languages of India]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in India]] [[Category:Scheduled Tribes of Manipur]]

{{Infobox person | name = Aleksandr Borisovich Zheleznyakov
Александр Борисович Железняков | image = Zheleznyakov_A_B-born_1957.jpg | caption = Aleksandr Zheleznyakov | residence = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|1|28}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]] | nationality = Russian | known_for = Engineer in Russian space program, writer, journalist | occupation = Russian rocket engineer }} '''Aleksandr Borisovich Zheleznyakov''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Бори́сович Железняко́в}}; born January 28, 1957)[http://publ.lib.ru/ARCHIVES/J/JELEZNYAKOV_Aleksandr_Borisovich/_Jeleznyakov_A.B..html Биография] is a specialist in design and production of rocket and space systems. He is also a writer and journalist. ==Biography== Zheleznyakov graduated from [[Saint Petersburg Polytechnical University|Kalinin Polytechnical Institute]] (now Saint Petersburg State Polytechnical University), as a physicist engineer in 1980. He worked as an engineer at the ''Impulse'' engineering plant in Leningrad from 1980 to 1981 and at the ''Krasnaya Zarya'' (Red Dawn) facility from 1983 to 1989, where he rose to head of department. In 1989 he moved to the ''Raduga'' (Rainbow) experimental design bureau where he worked as a senior manager until 2001. From 2001 to 2007 he worked as advisor to the Director and Chief Designer of the Central R&D Institute for Robotics and Technical Cybernetics in Saint Petersburg. Since 2007 has served as Advisor to the President of the [[S.P. Korolev Rocket and Space Corporation Energia]] in [[Korolyov (city)|Korolyov]]. Since 1989 he has written 17 books and hundreds of articles popularizing the achievements of Russian and world [[astronautics]]. He has used the pseudonyms "Aleksandr Yurkevich", "Aleksandr Borisov", "Konstantin Ivanov", "A.Zh." and "K.I.". ==Membership== *The Federation of Russian Cosmonautics *The Union of Journalists of Russia *The International Union of Journalists *The Union of Writers of St-Petersburg ==Awards and Prizes== *[[Order of Merit for the Fatherland|Medal of the Order of Merit for the Fatherland 2nd class]] (2007) *[[Medal "In Commemoration of the 300th Anniversary of Saint Petersburg"]] (2003) *Medal of Russian Aviation and Space Agency in the Honour of Forty-year Anniversary of the Spaceflight of Yuriy Gagarin *Medal for Merit of Federation of Russian Cosmonautics *Medals in the names of K. Tsiolkovsky, Y. Kondratyuk, S. Korolev, V. Glushko, M. Yangel, V. Tereshkova *Medal of the Ukraine National Space Agency after M. Yangel *Laureate of the [[Alexander Belyaev|A.R. Belyaev]] Literary Prize * [[Medal of the Order "For Merit to the Fatherland"]] I (2014){{Cite web |url=http://pravo.gov.ru:8080/page.aspx?91036 |title=Указ Президента Российской Федерации от 5 марта 2014 г. № 112 «О награждении государственными наградами Российской Федерации» |access-date=2016-02-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216214524/http://pravo.gov.ru:8080/page.aspx?91036 |archive-date=2016-02-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and II (2007){{Cite web |url=http://graph.document.kremlin.ru/page.aspx?915285 |title=Указ Президента Российской Федерации от 12 июня 2007 г. № 751 «О награждении государственными наградами Российской Федерации» |access-date=2016-02-11 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120710041202/http://graph.document.kremlin.ru/page.aspx?915285 |archive-date=2012-07-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }} degree ==Published books== *"Soviet Cosmonautics: the Chronicle of Emergencies and Catastrophes". St-Petersburg, 1998. *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1957." St-Petersburg, 2002.[http://www.cosmoworld.ru/spaceencyclopedia/publications/lke57.pdf Cosmoworld1] *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1958." St-Petersburg, 2002 *"When lifting off, the Rocket fell". St-Petersburg, 2003 *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1959." St-Petersburg, 2003 *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1960." St-Petersburg, 2003 *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1961." St-Petersburg, 2004 *"Secrets of Rocket Catastrophes". Moscow, 2004 *"Mir station: from triumph to...". St-Petersburg, 2006.[http://www.cosmoworld.ru/spaceencyclopedia/publications/mir.pdf Cosmoworld2] *"The Chronicles of the Space Age. Year 1962." St-Petersburg, 2006 *"The Space of Secret: myths and phantoms in the orbit". Moscow, 2006 *"Sex in Space". St-Petersburg, 2008. *"The Main Line: Poems". St-Petersburg, 2009 *"The first in space. How the Soviet Union defeated the United States". Moscow, 2011 *"Secret space. Were there Gagarin's predecessors?" Moscow, 2011 *"From Vostok to Rassvet". St-Peterburg, 2011 *"Secrets of the American spaceflight". Moscow, 2011 == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *Aleksandr Zheleznyakov's Encyclopedia Cosmonautics (http://www.cosmoworld.ru/spaceencyclopedia/) *Novosti Kosmonavtiki magazine's Space News (http://www.novosti-kosmonavtiki.ru/content/news.shtml). *Aleksandr Borisovich Zheleznyakov (http://astrovips.org/astro/en/person/8109/1.html) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zheleznyakov, Aleksandr Borisovich}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian engineers]] [[Category:Russian aerospace engineers]] [[Category:Soviet writers]] [[Category:Soviet journalists]] [[Category:Male journalists]] [[Category:Rocket scientists]] [[Category:Recipients of the Medal of the Order "For Merit to the Fatherland" I class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Medal of the Order "For Merit to the Fatherland" II class]] [[Category:20th-century Russian writers]] [[Category:Russian writers]] [[Category:Russian-language writers]] [[Category:20th-century Russian engineers]] [[Category:21st-century Russian engineers]] [[Category:20th-century Russian male writers]]

{{About|the Indo-European augment|the Bantu augment|Augment (Bantu languages)}} In [[linguistics]], the '''augment''' is a [[syllable]] added to the beginning of the word in certain [[Indo-European languages]], most notably [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]] and [[Indo-Iranian languages]] such as [[Sanskrit]], to form the past tenses. ==Indo-European languages== [[historical linguistics|Historical linguists]] are uncertain whether the augment is a feature that was added to some branches of Indo-European or whether the augment was present in the parent language and lost by all other branches (see also [[Proto-Greek language|Proto-Greek]]). ===Greek=== ====Ancient Greek==== In [[Ancient Greek]], the verb [[wikt:λέγω#Ancient Greek|λέγω]] ''légo'' “I say” has the aorist ἔλεξα ''élexa'' “I said”. The initial ε ''e'' is the augment. When it comes before a consonant, it is called the "syllabic augment" because it adds a syllable. Sometimes the syllabic augment appears before a vowel because the initial consonant of the verbal root (usually [[digamma]]) was lost:[[Herbert Weir Smyth]]. ''Greek Grammar''. [http://www.ccel.org/s/smyth/grammar/html/smyth_2Vo_uni.htm#429 par. 429]: syllabic augment. * *έ-ϝιδον *''é-widon'' → (loss of digamma) *ἔιδον *''éidon'' → ([[synaeresis]]) εἶδον ''eîdon'' When the augment is added before a vowel, the augment and the vowel are [[crasis|contracted]] and the vowel becomes [[vowel length|long]]: ''[[wikt:ἀκούω#Ancient Greek|akoúō]]'' "I hear", ''ḗkousa'' "I heard". It is sometimes called the "temporal augment" because it increases the time needed to pronounce the vowel.Smyth. [http://www.ccel.org/s/smyth/grammar/html/smyth_2Vo_uni.htm#435 par. 435]: temporal augment. ====Homeric Greek==== In [[Homer]], [[past tense|past-tense]] ([[aorist (Ancient Greek)|aorist]] or [[imperfect]]) verbs appeared both with and without an augment. *{{lang|grc|ὣς φάτο — ὣς ἔφατο}}
hṑs pháto — hṑs éphato
"so he/she said" *{{lang|grc|ἦμος δ᾿ ἠριγένεια '''φάνη''' ῥοδοδάκτυλος Ἠώς,}}
êmos d' ērigéneia '''phánē''' rhododáktulos Ēṓs,
"And when rose-fingered Dawn appeared, early-born," ====Modern Greek==== Unaccented syllabic augment disappeared during the [[Medieval Greek|Byzantine period]] as a result of the loss of unstressed initial syllables. However, accented syllabic augments remained in place.Browning, Robert (1983). Medieval and Modern Greek (p58). So Ancient ἔλυσα, ἐλύσαμεν "I loosened, we loosened" corresponds to Modern έλυσα, λύσαμε (''élisa'', ''lísame'').Sophroniou, S.A. ''Modern Greek''. Teach Yourself Books, 1962, Sevenoaks, p79. Temporal augment has not survived in the vernacular, which leaves the initial vowel unaltered: Ancient ἀγαπῶ, ἠγάπησα "I love, I loved"; Modern αγαπώ, αγάπησα (''agapó'', ''agápisa''). === Sanskrit === [[Sanskrit grammar#Aorist system|Sanskrit]] had the augment अ- / ''a-'', prefixed to past-tense verbs (aorist and imperfect). Coulson, Michael. ''Teach yourself Sanskrit''. p. 244. Hodder and Stoughton, 1976, Sevenoaks. {| class="wikitable" ! stem !! present !! aorist !! imperfect !! English |- | ध / dhã || दधति / dadhãti || अधत् / adhãt || अदधत् / adadhãt || put |- | गम् / gam || गच्छति / gacchati || अगमत् / agamat || अगच्छत् / agacchat || go |} === Other === * [[Phrygian language|Phrygian]] seems to have had an augment. * Classical [[Armenian language|Armenian]] had an augment,Clackson, James. 1994. ''The Linguistic Relationship Between Armenian and Greek.'' London: Publications of the Philological Society, No 30. (and Oxford: Blackwell Publishing) in the form of [[wikt:ե-|e-]]. * [[Yaghnobi language|Yaghnobi]], an [[Eastern Iranian languages|East Iranian]] language spoken in [[Tajikistan]], has an augment. ==Non-Indo-European languages== The term has also been extended to describe similar features in non-Indo-European languages. In [[Nahuatl]], the perfect ''ō-'' prefix is called an augment. In certain [[Bantu languages]] such as [[Zulu language|Zulu]], the term "augment" refers to the initial vowel of a noun class prefix such as (in Zulu) '''''u'''mu-'', '''''a'''ma-''. That vowel may be present or absent, according to grammatical rules. ==Constructed languages== In [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s [[Quenya|High Elvish]], the repetition of the first vowel before the perfect (for instance ''utúlië'', perfect tense of ''túlë'', "come") is also called an augment. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Indo-European linguistics]] [[Category:Linguistic morphology]] [[Category:Greek grammar]] [[Category:Phonology]]

'''Bankidas Ashiya''' was a [[Rajasthani Language|Rajasthani]] poet and scholar. He was from the [[Charan]] family of the [[India]]n state [[Rajasthan]]
He was born in 1771 (1828 Vikram Samvat). He has composed between 1803 and 1833. He wrote several religious poems, didactic poems and also on the then situation of the society.
He died in about 1833.
==Works==
His composed poems are: * Moha Mardana: a didactic poem * Anyokti Panchasika: an allegorical poem on morality * Krupana Darpana: ridiculing the misers * Mavadiya Mijaja: criticizing the effeminate persons * Chugala Mikha Chapetika: poem against sycophants * Vaisa Varta: poem condemning the prostitution * Vidura Battisi: on problems of illegitimate of maid-servants and servants * Duha Ayasaji Maharaja Devanatha Ra: On spiritual teacher of Maharaja Mansingh of [[Jodhpur]] * Jhamala Thakuran Rupsinghji Ra: on Rup singh, the son of Arjun Singh Udawata * Santosa Bavani: praising virtues of men and condemning their vices * Dhavala Pachchisi: On heroism, treating the bull as the symbol of hero * Niti Manjari: a poem on ethics * Gangalahari
Source:<ref>{{cite book|title=A History of Indian Literature|author=Sisir Kumar Das|page=814|publisher=Sahitya Akademi}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2009}} [[Image:ODU 03.jpg|thumb|right|BUC: Block upconverter, Ku band
Top: Hughes 1W
Bottom: [[Feed horn]] with short section of [[waveguide]], Andrew 2W BUC and Swedish microwave LNB]] [[Image:ODU 01.jpg|thumb|right|BUC: Block upconverter, Ku band
1.2 Andrew dish assembly]] {{Antennas|components}} A '''block upconverter''' ('''BUC''') is used in the [[transmission (telecommunications)|transmission]] ([[uplink]]) of [[satellite]] signals. It converts a band of [[frequencies]] from a lower frequency to a higher frequency. Modern BUCs convert from the [[L band]] to [[Ku band|Ku band]], [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and [[Ka band|Ka band]]. Older BUCs convert from a 70 [[megahertz|MHz]] intermediate frequency (IF) to Ku band or C band. Most BUCs use [[phase-locked loop]] local [[Electronic oscillator|oscillator]]s and require an external 10 MHz [[frequency reference]] to maintain the correct transmit frequency. BUCs used in remote locations are often 2 or 4 [[Watt|W]] in the [[Ku band|Ku band]] and 5 W in the C band. The 10 MHz reference frequency is usually sent on the same feedline as the main [[carrier wave|carrier]]. Many smaller BUCs also get their [[direct current]] (DC) over the feedline, using an internal DC block. BUCs are generally used in conjunction with [[low-noise block converter]]s (LNB). The BUC, being an up-converting device, makes up the "transmit" side of the system, while the LNB is the down-converting device and makes up the "receive" side. An example of a system utilizing both a BUC and an LNB is a [[very small aperture terminal|VSAT]] system, used for [[duplex (telecommunications)|bidirectional]] [[Internet]] access via satellite. The block upconverter is a block shaped device assembled with the LNB in association with an OMT, [[orthomode transducer|orthogonal mode transducer]] to the feed-horn that faces the reflector parabolic dish. This is opposed to other types of frequency upconverter which may be rack mounted indoors or not co-located with the dish. [[Category:Radio terminology]] [[Category:Satellite broadcasting]] [[Category:Telecommunications equipment]]

{{about|people who cull incoming calls|evaluating whether to answer a call or devices that do this|call screening}} A '''call screener''' or '''phone screener''' is a staff member who first answers the [[phone]] when audience members call into [[TV]] or [[radio]] broadcasts.
For call-in [[talk show]]s, screeners determine the air quality of the call (good connection or not) and if the caller's comments will further the topic or add a new point. Their job is to put the best calls on the air and filter out the callers that don't have anything worthwhile to add to the conversation. They also try to engage callers by acting as a "warm up" act for the host.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=SRudUtiUG6rqyQGA8YDIAQ&id=poUHAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22call+screener%22+tv+radio&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22call+screener%22 |first=Susan |last=Tyler Eastman |first2=Douglas A. |last2=Ferguson |title=Broadcast/cable/web programming: strategies and practices| publisher=Wadsworth/Thomson Learning |year=2002 |pages=423, 408–409 |isbn=9780534512958}}</ref><ref name="MediaProg">{{cite book|title=Media Programming: Strategies and Practices|edition= 9th|first=Susan Tyler |last=Eastman |first2=Douglas A. |last2=Ferguson |publisher=Cengage Learning |year=2012 |page=452 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SeoJAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA452&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=9781133712145}}</ref> Call screeners also typically provide a summary of pertinent information for the host or hosts to provide context for on air interaction, such as the caller's name, age, gender, location and a precis of what they intend to talk about.<ref name="UniversityUniversity1998">{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Richard|last2=Owen|first2=Diana|title=New Media and American Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mN5ZC-KSTaoC&pg=PA81|date=30 April 1998|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-19-535303-7|page=81}}</ref>
During breaking news events, screeners are responsible for verifying the caller's identity, to ensure that correct information will be presented to the news anchor. A failure here can allow an embarrassing on-air prank call through. [[Richard Roeper]] blamed call screeners in 2003 for a [[phone prank]]er getting through to [[Dan Rather]] live on-air during the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster]], by not checking the area code of the caller, who claimed to be an eyewitness in Texas.<ref name="Roeper03">[[Richard Roeper|Roeper, Richard]] (February 4, 2003). [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1476914.html "If only we'd all shut up when we've little to say"]. ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''{{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam]]}} p. 11. Retrieved 2012-11-30.</ref><ref name="NYPcolumbia">Mainelli, John (February 4, 2003). "Stern Laughs Along With Shuttle Phone Scam Sicko". ''[[New York Post]]''.</ref> A ''New York Post'' article about phone prankers describes call screeners as "overburdened and generally young producers assigned to act as gate-keepers", whose tools include "simply to ask would-be callers for their phone number and make sure the area code matches up with where they say they're calling from." An [[ABC News]] spokeswoman stated, "With breaking news we make every effort to ensure the credibility of the witness before we put them on the air, but in live events, screening processes are not 100 percent effective." An "industry vet" stated, "At the very least you can catch 90 percent of them by getting their number and calling them back, generally they freak or give you a phony phone number." Other techniques described "include grilling the caller on little known facts about the situation or organization they claim to represent."<ref>Kaplan, Don (August 19, 2003). [http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/item_QSgmbL10bqPO179yz4cReK "Phony Callers Crank It Up - Why TV News Can't Stop The Hoaxers"]. ''[[The New York Post]]''. NYP Holdings, Inc. Retrieved 2012-12-03.</ref> Prank callers don't always get through:<ref name="GrossAug04">{{cite news|last=Gross|first=Dan |date=August 23, 2004 |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DN&s_site=philly&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=104AAB8D738A7CE7&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Uncle June off to the races - Curses, foiled again |work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]] |page=43 |accessdate=2013-12-08 |quote=A call screener at WHYY 91 was able to divert Howard Stern prankster and North Wales gas station attendant Capt. Janks from getting on the air during an episode of Marty Moss-Coane's "Radio Times" last week. Janks had Stern on a three-way call and said Moss-Coane's name on Stern's air while on hold with the public radio station, which must have been tipped off because, according to Janks, a man came back on the line and called him an "a--hole" before cutting him off }}{{subscription required|via=[[NewsBank]]}}</ref>
==Notable call screeners== Although the names of most call screeners never make it on the air, there are a few notable screeners that are major characters on their shows.
* Joe Ardinger of the [[Don and Mike]] Show (said to be the oldest call screener in the world)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/97015/joe-ardinger-rejoining-don-geronimo-at-khtk |title=Joe Ardinger Rejoining Don Geronimo At KHTK |work= AllAccess.com |publisher=All Access Music Group |date=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> * Flipper [https://web.archive.org/web/20060816065803/http://www.flirtyflipper.com/] of the [[Sean Hannity]] show (liberal screener on conservative talk show){{citation needed|date=December 2013}} * Chunks of [[The Hideout (radio show)|The Hideout]] (call screener and stunt guy)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.notdeadyetradio.com/12-perfect-first-dates/ |title=12 – Perfect First Dates |work= Not Dead Yet Radio/ |date=March 3, 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref>{{not in citation|date=December 2016}} * Lindsay Delong of [[Dick and Skibba]] (call screener, news person, rapper, female perspective on a show aimed at men){{citation needed|date=December 2013}} * AP Mike of [[The Best Show with Tom Scharpling]] * [[Jason Stewart (call screener)|Jason Stewart]] (J-Stew) former "phone slap" of the [[Jim Rome Show]].
==Notable talk shows that do not use a call screeners== Many live call-in radio shows do not like alternative or adverse opinions to be aired, going through great lengths to screen out such calls. Because of that, it is rare that a live call-in talk show does not use call screeners. *The Love Doctors [https://wzzr.iheart.com/featured/the-love-doctors/] is a radio show broadcast in South Florida that has not used a call screener since its inception in 1989.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{BLP primary sources|date=November 2008}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Christian Vander | image = MAGMA @ Roadburn Festival 2017 02.jpg | image_size = 250 | landscape = yes | caption = Christian Vander at the [[Roadburn Festival]] 2017 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Christian Vander | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1948|2|21}} | birth_place = [[Nogent-sur-Marne]], Val-de-Marne, France | genre = [[Zeuhl]] | occupation = Musician | instrument = {{hlist|Drums|vocals|piano}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Magma (band)|Magma]]|[[Stella Vander]]}} }}
'''Christian Vander''' (born 21 February 1948 in [[Nogent-sur-Marne]], Val-de-Marne) is a French drummer, musician, and founder of the band [[Magma (band)|Magma]]. Besides his work with Magma, he has also performed solo, with the [[Christian Vander Trio]] and [[Christian Vander Quartet]], and in [[Offering (band)|Offering]].
Vander is known for his extended compositions, virtuosic drumming, and shrill falsetto improvisational/scat singing. His music fuses jazz, rock, classical and operatic influences, and draws on the work of musicians as diverse as [[John Coltrane]] and [[Carl Orff]]. Vander's music is broadly classified as [[progressive rock]], but the style is so unusual that it falls under its own category – an idiosyncratic style of music often referred to by fans as [[Zeuhl]] (which means "celestial" in [[Kobaïan]], a [[constructed language]] devised by Vander and used exclusively by Magma). There have been several other bands who have incorporated Zeuhl stylings into their compositions, many of which are composed of ex-Magma members. Some of the more notable groups of this variety include Japanese duo [[Ruins (Japanese band)|Ruins]], Magma offshoots [[Weidorje]] and [[Zao (French band)|Zao]], and Belgian chamber rock outfit [[Univers Zero]].
Christian Vander is the stepson of famous French jazz piano player [[Maurice Vander]] (who was a long time sideman of the French singer [[Claude Nougaro]]).
Most of Vander and Magma's recorded work is still available through Vander's own record label, [[Seventh Records]].
He was married to singer [[Stella Vander]] who released many [[Extended play|EP]]s herself in the 1960s and has performed vocal duties for Magma since 1972.
== Style of drumming ==
Vander uses specific rhythms - 5/8, 9/8, 7/8 with combination of 4/4 and 2/4 rhythms (inspired by [[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]], [[Béla Bartók|Bártók]], [[Carl Orff|Orff]]).
==See also== *[[Romantic Warriors II: A Progressive Music Saga About Rock in Opposition]] *[[Romantic Warriors II: Special Features DVD]]
==External links== *[http://www.seventhrecords.com/ Official site]
{{Magma}}

{{Refimprove|date=March 2012}} '''Chunking''' is a method of presenting [[information]] which splits [[concept]]s into small pieces or "chunks" of information to make [[reading (activity)|reading]] and understanding faster and easier. Chunking is especially useful for material presented on [[the web]] because readers tend to [[wikt:scan|scan]] for specific information on a [[web page]] rather than read the page sequentially.
Chunked content usually contains: * [[bullet (typography)|bullet]]ed lists * short sub[[wikt:heading|heading]]s * short [[Sentence (linguistics)|sentence]]s with one or two ideas per sentence * short [[paragraph]]s, even one-sentence paragraphs * easily scannable [[character (computer)|text]], with [[bold]]ing of key [[phrases]] * inline graphics to [[guide]] the [[Human eyes|eyes]] or illustrate points which would normally require more words
==Advantages of chunking== * Chunking helps [[Technology|technical]] [[wikt:communicator|communicators]] or [[marketer]]s convey information more efficiently * Chunking helps readers find what they are looking for quickly * Chunking allows material to be presented consistently from page to page, so users can apply previous [[knowledge]] of [[page layout]] and [[navigation]] and focus on the content rather than the [[presentation]]
The [[bite, snack and meal]] is a popular phrase for a specific means of chunking content.
==Disadvantages of chunking==
{{Empty section|date=September 2015}}
==References== * [http://web.mit.edu/hennig/www/presentations/nelinet/writing/chunking.html "Chunking the Content" - Writing for the Web: Guidelines for MIT Libraries] ''accessed January 16, 2015'' * [http://www.webstyleguide.com/wsg3/3-information-architecture/2-organizing-information.html#chunking "Organizing Your Information" - Web Style Guide] ''accessed January 16, 2015''

page.title: Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities

revision.text:
{{cleanup|reason=Lacks {{Tlg|Infobox government agency}}.|date=August 2018}} The '''Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities''' ('''CRL Rights Commission''') is an independent [[chapter nine institution]] in [[South Africa]]. It draws its mandate from the [[Constitution of South Africa|South African Constitution]] by way of the Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities Act of 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=CRL Act|url=http://www.crlcommission.org.za/crlact.php|publisher=crlcommission.org.za|accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref>
==Mandate== The CRL Rights Commission is mandated "to promote respect for and further the protection of the rights of cultural, religious and linguistic communities; promote and develop peace, friendship, humanity, tolerance, national unity among and within cultural, religious and linguistic communities on the basis of equality, non-discrimination and free association; to promote the right of communities to develop their historically diminished heritage and to recognise community councils".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=30600&tid=83341 |title=Preparatory engagement on the status of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Rights in South Africa will be held in KwaZulu-Natal province |publisher=info.gov.za |date=12 September 2012 |accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref>
==Vision and mission== The vision of the CRL Rights Commission is "a united South African nation that protects and promotes the cultural, religious and linguistic rights of all its diverse communities". Its mission is to "promote and protect the rights of cultural, religious and linguistic communities".<ref>{{cite web|title=Vision & Mission|url=http://www.crlcommission.org.za/visionmission.php|publisher=crlcommission.org.za|accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref>
==Commissioners== On 2 April 2014, 12 new commissioners of the CRL Commission were inaugurated at the Constitutional Court. This was subsequent to their appointment by President Jacob Zuma in terms of section 11(4) read with 13(1) of the CRL Rights Commission Act 19 of 2002 with effect from 1 March 2014, for a period of five years. The inauguration ceremony was presided over by Justice Edwin Cameron.The 12 new members of the CRL Rights Commission are:
Ms Thoko Nonhle Mkhwanazi-Xaluva (Chairperson)
Prof Luka David Mosoma (Deputy Chairperson)
Dr Anton Wynard Knoetze
Mr Renier Stephanus Schoeman
Mr Sicelo Emmanuel Dlamini
Mr Raymond Trollip
Mr Richard Daryll Botha
Ms Violet Nomalanga Tyamzashe
Ms Bernedette Muthien
Ms Pumla Primrose Madiba
Ms Helen Julia Mabale
Ms Sheila Fihliwe Khama.<ref>{{cite web|title=Commissioners |url=http://www.crlcommission.org.za/commissioners.php |publisher=crlcommission.org.za |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Religion in South Africa]] * [[South African Charter of Religious Rights and Freedoms]] * [http://www.kas.de/suedafrika/en/ Partner: Konrad-Adenauer-Foundation]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.crlcommission.org.za/ Official site of the CRL Rights Commission]

{{inline|date=June 2017}}The '''State Commission of the Lithuanian Language''' ({{lang-lt|Valstybinė lietuvių kalbos komisija}}) is the official [[List of language regulators|language regulating body]] of the [[Lithuanian language]].
The Language Commission was put in operation in 1961 as a non-governmental entity under the auspices of the [[Lithuanian Academy of Sciences]].
Now, it is a state-run institution, founded under the auspices of the [[Seimas]] (parliament) of Lithuania. The mandate of the Commission comprises not only regulation and standardisation of the language, but also implementation of the official language status. Commission decrees on linguistic issues are compulsory by law to all companies, agencies, institutions, and the media in Lithuania.
==External links== * [http://www.vlkk.lt/en/ Official webpage] * [http://www3.lrs.lt/pls/inter2/dokpaieska.showdoc_e?p_id=157640 Amendment of the Republic of Lithuania law on the status of the state commission of the Lithuanian language]
[[Category:Language regulators]] [[Category:Lithuanian language]]

A '''do not call list''' or '''do not call registry''' is a list of personal [[Telephone number|phone numbers]] that are off-limits to [[Telemarketing|telemarketers]] in some countries. Specific examples include:
* [[Do Not Call Register]] (Australia) * [[National Do Not Call List]] (Canada) * [[Do Not Disturb Registry|National Customer Preference Register]] (India) * [[New Zealand Name Removal Service]] * [[Telephone Preference Service]] (United Kingdom) * [[National Do Not Call Registry]] (United States) * Do Not Call Registry (Singapore) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnc.gov.sg/index.html |title=PDPC - Do Not Call Registry |date= |accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.darrensim.com/2013/12/20/protect-spam-messages-singapore-pdpc-call-registry-dncr-starting-jul-2014/ |title=A Consumer Guide to the DNC |date= |accessdate=31 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101010525/http://www.darrensim.com/2013/12/20/protect-spam-messages-singapore-pdpc-call-registry-dncr-starting-jul-2014/ |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==History of the Do-Not-Call Registry== Consistent consumer complaints spurred Congress to sign the Telephone Consumer Protection ACT (TCPA) in 1991. The TCPA outlined new restrictions on sales calls and the use of automated dialers and voicemail recordings. It also suggested the creation of a database of consumer phone numbers that shouldn’t receive unsolicited sales calls.
While the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) adopted the TCPA guidelines, they chose not to move forward with the establishment of the phone number database.
That changed on June 27, 2003, when the FTC finally set up the Do-Not-Call Registry. Consumers could now register their phone number, and after 31 days unsolicited calls to that number were prohibited and punishable with a fine.
Within just 4 days, over 10 million phone numbers had been registered. By the registry’s seventh birthday (2010) that number had topped 200 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.phoneburner.com/blog/a-comprehensive-guide-to-the-do-not-call-registry/ |title=A Comprehensive Guide to the Do-Not-Call Registry |date= |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
==Internal Do-Not-Call Lists==
Do not call lists also exist internally. Entities making calls must honor requests from residential telephone subscribers not to receive calls, and must record the request, and the subscriber's name and telephone number, on its internal "do-not-call" list. The request must be honored within a reasonable time, not to exceed 30 days of the request.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.compliancepoint.com/rc-articles-what-needs-to-be-in-your-internal-do-not-call-policy-and-when-must-you-provide-it/ |title=What Needs to be in Your Internal Do Not Call Policy and When Must You Provide It? |date= |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Robinson list]], a UK opt-out registry of people who do not wish to receive marketing communications
== References == {{reflist}}

[[File:DuplexCancellation1902.jpg|300px|thumb|Misapplied duplex cancellation which failed to obliterate the postal stationery indicium.]] A '''duplex canceller''' was a hand stamp used to [[Cancellation (mail)|cancel]] [[postage stamp]]s and imprint a dated [[postmark]] applied simultaneously with the one device.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://linnsstampnews.com/howto/refresher/covers_20050627/refreshercourse.aspx |title=Cover collecting has its own terminology |publisher=[[Linn's Stamp News]] |accessdate=2009-05-07 |last=Miller |first=Rick }}</ref> The device had a steel die, generally circular, which printed the location of the cancel, together with the time and date of cancel. This die was held in place by a handle with an obliteration marker, often oval shaped, off to the right side that was applied over the postage stamp to prevent its reuse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://linnsstampnews.com/howto/refresher/postmarks_20020401/refreshercourse.aspx |title=Postmarks, cancels offer challenge and fun |publisher=[[Linn's Stamp News]]|last=Klug |first=Janet }}</ref> The ink came from an ink pad.
In many countries the [[Coded postal obliterators|obliterator part of the canceller]] was coded, in various ways, to identify the post office.
In the United States, they were first used in the 1860s and use continued into the 1940s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usstamps.org/glossary-term/duplex/ |title=Glossary of Terms for the Collector of United States Stamps |publisher=[[United States Stamp Society]] |accessdate=2017-09-15 }}</ref>
Some machine cancelling devices like the French [[Daguin machine]] or the Italian [[Dani Machine]] also applied both the "killer" and the date stamp simultaneously. Especially in the Italian literature (and in German literature about Italian cancels) these cancelling devices are referred as '''duplex cancel'''.

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox writer | name = Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma | image = Eeltje Hiddes Halbertsma.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_date = October 8, 1797 | birth_place = [[Grou]] ([[Netherlands]]) | death_date = {{death date and age|1858|03|22|1797|10|08}} | death_place = Grou (Netherlands) | occupation = physician, poet, writer | language = [[West Frisian language|West Frisian]] | citizenship = [[File:Flag of the Netherlands.svg|20px]] [[Netherlands|Dutch]] | nationality = [[File:Frisian flag.svg|20px]] [[West Frisians|Western Frisian]] | period = 19th century | movement = [[Romanticism]]Breuker 2016, p. 1123. | genre = poetry, short stories | notableworks = ''[[Rimen en Teltsjes]]''
''[[De Alde Friezen]]'' | spouse = Baukje Fockens | children = 2 sons (Hidde and Liuwe),
2 daughters (Ruerdtsje and Anna) | years_active = 1822–1858 }} '''Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma''' ([[West Frisian language|Frisian]] form: Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma, pron. [ˈeːlʧǝ ˈhɪdəs ˈhɔlbǝtsma] (the r is silent); [[Dutch language|Dutch]] form: '''Eeltje Hiddes Halbertsma''', pron. [ˈeːlcǝ ˈhɪdəs ˈhalbǝrtsma]) ([[Grou]], October 8, 1797 – there, March 22, 1858),Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123. was a Dutch [[West Frisians|Frisian]] writer, poet and physician,Breuker 1993, pp. 592–594. and the youngest of the [[Halbertsma Brothers]].Breuker 1993, p. 587. He became well known when he and his elder brother [[Justus Hiddes Halbertsma|Justus]] published the [[poetry collection|poetry]] and [[short story collection]] ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' in 1822.Breuker 1993, p. 594.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37. Afterwards, this work was continually expanded, and also came to include contributions by a third brother, [[Tsjalling Hiddes Halbertsma|Tsjalling]],Wiersma, p. 9. until all the Halbertsma Brothers' [[prose]] and poetry was posthumously collected in 1871 to become the famous work ''[[Rimen en Teltsjes]]''.Breuker 1993, pp. 603–606.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37. This book played a role of crucial importance in the development of a new literary tradition after Western Frisian had been used almost exclusively as a [[spoken language]] for three centuries.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Jensma, p. 197. Of the three Brothers Halbertsma, Eeltsje was probably the most talented, en especially his poetry is still very much admired.Breuker 1993, pp. 592–594.Wiersma, pp. 9–10. His [[Work of art|oeuvre]] included the poem ''[[De Alde Friezen]]'', which later became the [[national anthem]] of the [[West Frisians|Western Frisian people]].''Fryslân Sjongt'', pp. 10–11.Oppewal and Boorsma, pp. 90–93. ==Life== ===Youth and background=== Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma was born on October 8, 1797,Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Wiersma, p. 7. in his parents' house on Kowemerk ("Cow Market") streetWiersma, p. 7. in the village of [[Grou]], in the central part of the Dutch province of [[Friesland]].Breuker 1993, p. 592. He was the fourth son of the baker and small-time [[merchant]]Breuker 1993, p. 587.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Wiersma, p. 7. Hidde Joasts Halbertsma (1756–1809)Breuker 1993, p. 587.Terpstra, p. 317. and his wife Ruerdtsje (or Riurtk)Wiersma, p. 7. Tsjallings Binnerts (1767–1809).Breuker 1993, p. 587.Terpstra, p. 317.Wiersma, pp. 7–8. He had three elder brothers: [[Justus Hiddes Halbertsma|Justus ("Joast")]] (1789–1869),Breuker 1993, p. 588.Terpstra, p. 316.Wiersma, p. 7. [[Tsjalling Hiddes Halbertsma|Tsjalling]] (1792–1852),Breuker 1993, p. 591.Terpstra, p. 316.Wiersma, p. 7. and Binnert (1795–1847).Breuker 1993, p. 587.Terpstra, p. 316.Wiersma, p. 7. Two children who were born later died in early childhood,Terpstra, p. 316. the little boy in 1803,Wiersma, p. 7. and the little girl in 1805.Wiersma, p. 7. The brothers were very close, possibly as a consequence of the fact that both their parents died at a relatively young age in 1809, when Eeltsje was only eleven years of age.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Terpstra, p. 317.Wiersma, pp. 8–9. Justus, Tsjalling and Eeltsje, who, as authors, became known as the [[Brothers Halbertsma]] later in life,Hemminga, p. 56.Jensma, p. 197. were much like their father, while Binnert more resembled their mother.Breuker 1993, p. 587. This mother, Ruerdtsje Binnerts, was a scion of a prominent family in Grou.Breuker 1993, p. 587.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16. Her people were [[Mennonites]],Breuker 1993, p. 587.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16. and although her husband had been raised a [[Calvinism|Calvinist]], he converted after marrying her.Breuker 1993, p. 587. From the letters of Eeltsje's brother Justus Ruerdtsje emerges as a smart businesswoman,Breuker 1993, p. 587. a loving mother, and a deeply religious person.Wiersma, p. 8. About Hidde Halbertsma, the father, much less is known. It is thought that he might have been a [[mariner]] before his marriage.Wiersma, p. 8. He is described as a gentle soul, who was, however, apt to take offence, and could be quite sharp-tongued in such cases.Wiersma, p. 8. In 1784, he published a long [[Dutch language|Dutch-language]] poem under the title ''Schrikkelijke IJsgang en Overstroominge in Gelderland'' ("Terrible Ice-drift and Flooding in [[Gelderland]]").Wiersma, p. 8. From this intriguing work it is clear that his sons' literary talents ran in the family.Wiersma, p. 8. ===Education=== Like his elder brother Justus, Eeltsje Halbertsma was sent to the French school in the provincial capital of [[Leeuwarden]] for a year by his mother,Breuker 1993, p. 587. and after that, he was enrolled in the [[Latin school]], also in Leeuwarden.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Wiersma, p. 9. There, he started following lessons probably just before Ruerdtsje Binnerts' death in December 1809.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Wiersma, p. 9. As their father, Hidde Halbertsma, hat died in January of that same year, the brothers became [[orphan]]s because of this unfortunate event.Wiersma, pp. 8–9. Justus, the eldest brother, was studying in [[Amsterdam]] at the time.Wiersma, p. 9. Eeltsje could continue his education in the Latin school because the middle brothers, Tsjalling and Binnert, kept their father's bakery running with the help of their father's baker's mates.Wiersma, p. 9. As [[commuter|commuting]] from Grou to Leeuwarden and back again on a daily basis was out of the question with roads and transportation being what they were at that time, Eeltjse [[boarding house|boarded]] in the city with one Hawerdink, an acquaintance of his brother Justus, who apparently introduced him to the most vulgar form of [[Stadsfries dialects|City Frisian]], a Dutch (not Frisian) dialect which is spoken in the cities in Friesland.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123. When he had finished his training in the Latin school, towards the end of 1814,Breuker 1993, p. 592. Eeltsje Halbertsma left for [[Holland]], where he started a study of medicine at the [[University of Leiden]] which lasted until April 1818.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Twerda, p. 296.Wiersma, p. 9. In the student city of [[Leiden]], however, he became caught up in the rough night life,Breuker 1993, p. 592. and that was why, by way of reorientation, he left for [[Heidelberg]], in Germany, for half a year in the spring of 1818.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1124.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Twerda, pp. 296–297.Wiersma, p. 9. There he enjoyed himself tremendously at the [[Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg|Ruprecht-Karls-Universität]], and later in his life he always looked back on his Heidelberg period with a sense of whistfulness.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Terpstra, p. 318.Wiersma, p. 10. The lessons he followed in Heidelberg for the most part had to do with [[obstetrics]].Breuker 1993, p. 592. After the summer, he returned to Leiden, where he ended his study by obtaining his doctorate in medicine on October 13, 1818.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Wiersma, p. 10. Afterwards, Halbertsma became physician in [[Purmerend]], in [[North Holland|northern Holland]],Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Wiersma, p. 10. where he lived for a year and a half,Breuker 1993, p. 592. and also became involved with a local girl whom he referred to as "the Little Peacock" in his letters to his brother Justus.Wiersma, p. 10. Eventually, though, he became ill, and was brought back to his family in Grou, probably towards the end of 1820.Breuker 1993, p. 592. When he had recovered, he did not go back to Holland, but instead started a practice in the village where he was born. He would spend the rest of his life there,Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Wiersma, p. 10. because, he wrote to his brother Justus, "Grou is alway lovely to me."Terpstra, p. 318.Wiersma, p. 10. Because of his good education, but also because of his compassionate bedside manner, Halbertsma had a very spread-out practice, with patients not only in Grou, but also scattered around the [[countryside]] and in neighbouring villages. This required him to travel a lot, for which he often had to depend on boats in the marshy lake country of Central Friesland.Terpstra, p. 319. ===Nature and views=== From stories of people who knew him, Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma emerges as a man who was quickly moved, but could also have a lot of fun.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Wiersma, p. 9. According to the bookseller and historian Wopke Eekhoff, who was acquainted with him for many years, Halbertsma was big-hearted and generous, and a droll story-teller.Breuker 1993, p. 592. One of Halbertsma's biographers described him as "a fine-feeling spirit, an idealistic dreamer, an independent and courageous man, afflicted by periods of [[depression (mood)|melancholy]] and [[doubt]]; a ''[[bohémien]]'' and a rascal, such as there has been no second of in all of Western Frisian literature."Wiersma, p. 13. Halbertsma's letters to his brother Justus are lively and open-hearted, and also quite entertaining still.Breuker 1993, p. 592. As for his views, Halbertsma had become influenced by [[Deism]] in his student days, but according to himself he had changed his opinion after reading the German philosopher [[Johann Gottfried Herder]].Breuker 1993, p. 592. Politics Halbertsma tried to stay away from. In the company of others he was sometimes seduced into speaking on that subject, but he was always afraid to say too much; his father had been a supporter of the [[Patriots (Dutch Republic)|Patriot movement]], and Halbertsma could never forget how badly that had ended.Breuker 1993, p. 592. For all that, he did not just stand by when his sense of justice was violated, as is shown by his poems ''De Grytman'' ("The [[Grietman]]"; about corruption in the political upper classes in Friesland) and ''Batthyany's Dea'' ("Batthyany's Death"; about the execution of [[Lajos Batthyány]], the leader of the [[Hungarians]] in the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848–49|Hungarian Rebellion of 1848–1849]]).Breuker 1993, p. 592. He also wrote, in [[Dutch language|Dutch]], a poem in which he rages against the fact that Frisian members of the [[Tweede Kamer]] voted against the proposal to abolish [[slavery]] in 1853.Breuker 1993, p. 593. On the other hand, he was not so progressive that he felt himself in any way connected with those he called, in 1855, "red democrats" (that is to say socialists and other political [[political radicalism|radicals]]), whom he separated from "the decent-minded", with which he meant the progressive, liberal section of the settled middle class, to which he himself belonged.Breuker 1993, p. 593. In 1827, Halbertsma became a member of the Provinciaal Friesch Genootschap ter Beoefening van Friesche Geschied-, Oudheid- en Taalkunde ("Provincial Frisian Society for the Study of Frisian History, Antiquities and Linguistics"), but in 1834, he cancelled his membership because he felt this club was full to the rafters with silly people.Van der Schaaf, p. 38 He could not stomach the affected poshness of the middle class gentlemen, and neither could he reconcile such graveness of bearing with the 'gluttony and wine-guzzling' which followed the gatherings. "''Es gibt Narren aller Art''" ("It takes fools of all kinds"), he wrote to his brother Justus.Van der Schaaf, p. 38 Justus did stay a member of the society, but because he was a [[Mennonites|Mennonite]] [[minister (Christianity)|minister]] in [[Deventer]], in the province of [[Overijssel]], and was therefore mostly a member by correspondence, it was somewhat easier for him to look at things with a certain detachment.Van der Schaaf, p. 38 Later, Eeltsje Halbertsma became a member of the Selskip foar Fryske Taal en Skriftekennisse ("Society for Knowledge of Frisian Language and Literature"), where he felt much more at home.[source needed] [[File:Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma, gable stone in his birth house in Grou.jpg|left|thumb|200px|[[Gable stone]] with the likeness of Eeltsje Halbertsma in the front wall of the house of his birth in [[Grou]].]] ===Family=== In June 1823, Halbertsma married Baukje Fockens (1795–1877),Breuker 1993, p. 592.Wiersma, p. 10. a woman from a well-to-do family from [[Bolsward]],Breuker 1993, p. 592. whom he had met in the autumn of 1822.Breuker 1993, p. 592. She was the daughter of Livius (Liuwe) Regnerus Fockens, a mayor of Bolsward who had died not long before.Wiersma, p. 10. Halbertsma and his wife had four children: two sons and two daughters. Only their son Hidde would survive his father, as the other son, Liuwe, died in 1854, and both of the girls, Ruerdtsje and Anna, were laid to rest yn 1851.Breuker 1993, p. 592. The death of Anna (1832–1851), with whom he was exceptionally close, hit Halbertsma especially hard; about this loss he wrote the touching poem ''Op Anna's Dea'' ("On Anna's Death"),Breuker 1993, p. 592. which was published in 1854, in the poetry and short story collection ''Leed en Wille en de Flotgerzen'' ("Grief and Pleasure and Down Upon the Lee Shore").Brothers Halbertsma 1958, p. 347.Brothers Halbertsma 1993, p. 258-259. Halbertsma's marriage was, after the first few years,Terpstra, p. 319. not very happy,Breuker 1993, p. 592.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Terpstra, p. 319. as he was much too fond of alcohol,Breuker 1993, p. 592.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Terpstra, p. 319. while his wife nagged constantly, was distrustful and reproached him continuously for living off her money.Breuker 1993, p. 592. It is therefore probably not coincidental that in several of Halbertsma's stories the main characters are a drunken man and his angry wife.Breuker 1993, p. 592. In 1853, when both marriage partners had neglected their household for years, the parents were placed under [[guardianship]] by both of their sons, which was done especially on the initiative of Liuwe.Breuker 1993, p. 592. Although Halbertsma managed to become his own master again in 1857, this was a humiliation for which it was not easy for him to forgive his son, and there is no [[elegy]] for Liuwe's passing in 1854, as Halbertsma did make for both of his daughters.Breuker 1993, p. 592. ===Writing career=== Halbertsma felt the drive to write for the first time, as his brother [[Justus Hiddes Halbertsma|Justus]] would later tell it, when he came back from his half-year in [[Heidelberg]], and noticed that the [[song|street song]]s in the [[Netherlands]] were of a very low quality compared to those in Germany. According to Justus, Eeltsje Halbertsma set out writing poetry to replace the existing songs with better ones of his own making.Breuker 1993, p. 593. The [[linguist]] Philippus H. Breuker, who added an extensive and penetrating [[afterword]] to the [[reprint]] of ''[[Rimen en Teltsjes]]'' of 1993, observed, however, that this assertion could "never be more than half the truth," as Halbertsma's early poetry was not of a high literary value; quite the opposite, in fact. According to Breuker, it seems more likely that Halbertsma wanted to emulate these Dutch street songs.Breuker 1993, p. 593. Later on, he must have come under the influence of Justus' ideas, who wanted to preserve the [[Western Frisian language]] by reintroducing it for writing after it had been used almost exclusively as a [[spoken language]] for three centuries.Boelens et al., p. 116.Breuker 1993, p. 589.Wiersma, p. 11. From that it followed that Justus had to get the Frisians to read in their own language (otherwise, writing it would not be of much use), and to achieve that aim, he set out writing the sort of [[folk literature]] which dovetailed nicely with Eeltsje Halbertsma's work.Wiersma, p. 11. As Justus remained the editor of Eeltsje's work for his entire life, their poetry and [[short fiction]] were strongly connected and published together from the very beginning.Breuker 1993, p. 593. Although writing short stories and poems was something which Eeltsje Halbertsma could not do without, from approximately 1830 onwards the social prestige he won with it also started to play a role.Breuker 1993, p. 593. In 1822, the best of the early works of Eeltsje and Justus were collected under the title ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' ("Gabe Tailor's Rag Basket"; original, archaic [[spelling]]: ''De Lape Koer fen Gabe Skroor''), a booklet consisting of 36 pages, and including six poems and one short story.Breuker 2016, p. 1124.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37. This publication was attributed to the fictional 'Gabe Skroar', a lame farmer's son who became a tailor and a writer, but died young.Breuker 1993, p. 597.Twerda, p. 297. This character was in all probability a creation of Eeltsje's.Breuker 1993, p. 597. Hiding behind such a fictional author was fairly normal at that time.Breuker 1993, p. 597.Twerda, p. 297. A second, expanded edition of ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'', consisting of 237 pages, was published in 1829, followed by a third, further expanded edition in 1834, running to almost 500 pages of a larger size.Breuker 2016, p. 1124.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Terpstra, p. 313.Twerda, p. 298.Wiersma, pp. 5, 11. After that, additions were published separately in 1836 (''De Noarger Rún oan Gabe Skroar''), 1840 (''Twigen út in Alde Stamme''), 1854 (''Leed en Wille en de Flotgerzen''), and 1858 (''De Jonkerboer'' and ''Teltsjes fan de Wize Mannen fan Esonstêd'').Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Brothers Halbertsma 1958, p. 589-594. Eeltsje Halbertsma was almost certainly the most talented of the three writing [[Halbertsma Brothers]].Breuker 1993, pp. 592–594.Wiersma, pp. 9–10. While Tsjalling's works were purely intended for entertainment, and Justus composed his stories and poetry in a somewhat distant, cerebral way, which keeps the reader a little detached from what is read, Eeltsje put his soul and heart into his poems and stories.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 17. It is this [[emotion]] which brings his work closer to the reader. Furthermore, Eeltsje's prose and poetry are in proportion to each other, qualitatively, while in Justus' works the poetry is generally quite clearly not of the same high standing as his prose.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. In the middle of the 20th century the author and [[literary critic]] Anne Wadman stated that Eeltsje was the greatest poet of his time in the Netherlands; as neither [[Willem Bilderdijk]] nor [[Isaäc da Costa]] were fit to hold a candle to him (he wrote), one would look invain for someone of the same stature in the [[Dutch literature]] of that period.Breuker 1993, p. 595. On the basis of [[Romanticism]], which he had acquired in [[Heidelberg]],Breuker 2016, p. 1124.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Twerda, p. 297.Wiersma, p. 9. Eeltsje Halbertsma often needed a first impulse for his works, an existing text or melody that he could, as he himself put it, [[Western Frisian language|frisify]] "in such a way that no one could recognise the original anymore."Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. Because of this it is thought that the masterful ''Jonker Pyt en Sibbel'' ("Squire Pete and Sibylle") could possibly be a much improved version of the Dutch-language poem ''Steedsche Jonker en een Friessche Boerin'' ("City Squire and a Frisian Farmer's Wife"), from the 18th century.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. It is beyond dispute that Halbertsma based some of his poetry on earlier works by such poets as [[Johann Peter Hebel]] and [[Ludwig Hölty]].Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. For instance, ''De Boalserter Merke'' ("The Bolsward Fair"), still one of his most well-known works, is a ''Nachdichtung'' of Hebel's lovesong ''Hans und Verene'', in which the main characters were renamed Hoatse and Wobbel, the background was shifted from a German well to a [[fair]] in the Frisian city of [[Bolsward]], and quite a few smaller changes were made.Terpstra, p. 318.Wiersma, p. 10. An example of a poem based on Hölty's work is the somewhat morbid ''Deagraverssankje'' ("Grave-digger's Song").Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40.Terpstra, p. 314. Though Halbertsma often wrote [[idyll]]ic poems in his early years, such as ''It Marke'' ("The Little Lake") and ''Geale' Sliepke'' ("Geale's Nap"), and, to a lesser degree, ''It Famke'' ("The Girl"), later the circumstances of his family life and professional difficulties so depressed him that he wrote, "you [will] find in my last works nothing of that [[Arcadia (utopia)|Arcadia]]."Wiersma, p. 13. In its place came moving [[elegy|elegies]], such as ''De Likeblommen'' ("The [[Leek, Netherlands|Leek]] Flowers"), ''Op Anna's Dea'' ("On Anna's Death"), and ''It Tsjerkhôf by Jûntiid'' ("The Churchyard in the Evening"), and also poems such as ''It Libbensein'' ("Life's End"), and ''Deagraverssankje'' ("Grave-digger's Song"), which reflect upon the transitory nature of human existence.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. Halbertsma was, however, also the author of the mildly humorous ''Ald Jan-om'' ("Old Uncle John"), in which a farm-hand of advanced years complains of the farmer's daughter's constant stream of suitors, who are always getting in his way,Brothers Halbertsma 1958, p. 46. and of the love poem ''Skipperssankje'' ("Skipper's Song"), an entreaty of a [[mariner]] to his beloved to not forget him, even if his ship should sink and he should drown.''Fryslân Sjongt'', p. 66-67. The appreciation for Halbertsma's strongly [[retorics|retorical]] [[hymn|freedom hymns]] has eroded in the course of the 20th century,Breuker 2016, p. 1124. but even so, the [[nationalism|nationalistic]] song ''[[De Alde Friezen]]'',''Fryslân Sjongt'', p. 10-11.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 17, 90–93.Terpstra, p. 319. is still the [[national anthem]] of the [[Western Frisian people]], which it was proclaimed to be yn 1875 (in a thoroughly revised version by Jacobus van Loon).Breuker 2016, p. 1124.''Fryslân Sjongt'', p. 10-11.Schroor, p. 2831. In his [[prose]] Halbertsma shows himself to be a smooth story-teller, occasionally using a poetic-[[realism (arts)|realistic]] approach, such as in the story ''Utfanhûs by de Boer'' ("Staying the Night on the Farm"), at other times becoming [[irony|ironic]], such as in ''De Klúnskonk fan Us Ald Dominy'' ("The Skate-walking Leg of Our Old Minister").Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. ''De Noarger Rún oan Gabe Skroar'' ("The [[Norg]] Gelding to Gabe Tailor"), which has the form of a letter from the afterlife to Gabe Tailor, written by his dead horse, is a satire, while in ''De Reis nei de Jichtmasters'' ("The Journey to the Gout Masters") Halbertsma uses mild humour and a little mockery to poke fun at his own medical profession.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. In the longer story ''De Jonkerboer'' ("The Gentleman Farmer"), which some [[literary critic|critics]] call a novella,Breuker 2016, p. 1123. the main [[motif (literature)|motif]] is a longing for a peaceful and diligent existence in the country-side.Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. That same feeling is also embodied by ''De Quickborn'' ("The Quickborn"), a choice of poems Halbertsma translated very freely from the poetry collection of the same name which was originally written in the [[Low German language|Low German]] [[dialect]] of the northern German region of [[Dithmarschen]] by [[Klaus Groth]].Breuker 2016, p. 1123.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 41. [[File:Grou, Dr. Eeltsje Halbertsma Earebyld.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The statue of Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma in [[Grou]].]] Striking things about Eeltsje Halbertsma's literary works are the wonderful sound patterns in some of his poems, especially ''Geale' Sliepke'' ("Geale's Nap"),Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. and his playful additions of phrases in other languages or dialects, which occur mostly in his stories, but also in some poems, like ''Jonker Pyt and Sibbel'' ("Squire Pete and Sibylle"), where the [[squire]] has just returned from fashionable France, and now believes it shows his breeding and social status to throw around French words and phrases.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40.Brothers Halbertsma 1958, pp. 18–20.Brothers Halbertsma 1993, pp. 11–12. "[[Gibberish]], odd names, strange types of people, [[filler (linguistics)|stopgap word]]s, [...] the most surprising [[metaphor]]s, and the most unexpected jumps in a [[train of thought]],"Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 40. all of this occurs regularly in Halbertsma's prose.Breuker 2016, p. 1123. In his works he is guided by the ideal image he had in his mind of the Western Frisians as simple but genuine people, which he contrasts against the [[Dutch people|Dutch]], who were in his eyes refined but insincere.Breuker 2016, p. 1123. ===Death=== In his last years there was not much which connected Halbertsma to the village of [[Grou]]. Because of his unhappy marriage, he could not find solace at home,Breuker 1993, p. 592. and the death of his daughter Anna, in 1851, had made him lose his cheerfulness.Breuker 1993, p. 592. The following year his brother [[Tsjalling Hiddes Halbertsma|Tsjalling]] also died, who had been the steadfast centre of the family.Breuker 1993, p. 588. That is why Eeltsje, after he had transferred his medical practice to his son Hidde in 1856,Breuker 1993, p. 592. started a wandering life visiting family members who lived far away.Breuker 1993, p. 592. Later on, he lived for little while by himself in [[Leeuwarden]],Breuker 1993, p. 592. but a few weeks before his death he arranged to be brought back to Grou.Breuker 1993, p. 592. He died there on March 22, 1858, when he was sixty years old.Breuker 1993, p. 592.Breuker 2016, p. 1123. He was buried in a double-deep grave which later came to lie outside of the churchyard boundaries, and is now marked by three red stones in an otherwise yellow-paved pathway.Breuker 1993, p. 592. ==Legacy== After the death of all three [[Brothers Halbertsma]], their short fiction and poetry was gathered under the supervision of librarian and archivist Gerben Colmjon and bookseller and historian Wopke Eekhoff.Breuker 1993, p. 604.Wiersma, p. 5. In 1871, it was published by the firm of J. de Lange in [[Deventer]], under the title of ''[[Rimen en Teltsjes]]'' ("Rhymes and Tales").Breuker 1993, pp. 603–606.Breuker 2016, p. 1124.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16.Terpstra, p. 313.Wiersma, p. 5. This work is now thought of as the national book of Western Frisian literature,Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Oppewal and Boorsma, p. 16. and although the [[literature|literary]] value of this collection was later disputed by some [[literary critic|critcs]],Breuker 1993, pp. 594–596. it is undeniable that ''Rimen en Teltsjes'' and its predecessor ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' played a role of crucial importance in the development of a new literary tradition after Western Frisian had been used almost exclusively as a spoken language for three centuries.Dykstra and Oldenhof, p. 37.Jensma, p. 197. In 1949, the author and literary critic Anne Wadman wrote that the Halbertsmas gave "the Western Frisian people a literary monument, in which it saw its own life as a nation [...] reflected."Wadman, p. 14. As of today ''Rimen en Teltsjes'' still occupies the first slot in the ranking of Western Frisian literary classics.Jensma, p. 197. In 1993, the tenth [[reprint]] of the book was published, including for the first time some (earlier, lower-quality) work of Eeltsje Halbertsma which had until then remained outside of ''Rimen en Teltsjes''.Breuker 1993, p. 610. This reprint had a (for Western Frisian literature) ambitious printing of 3,000 copies, but was sold out within two months.Breuker 2016, p. 1124. The Selskip foar Fryske Taal en Skriftekennisse hired the sculptor Willem Molkenboer in 1875, to make a [[stone tablet]] in which the likeness of Eeltsje Hiddes Halbertsma was chiselled out. This was placed as a [[gable stone]] in the front wall of the house where the Halbertsma Brothers were born, on what later was renamed Halbertsmaplein ("Halbertsma Square").Koopmans, p. 309.Twerda, p. 299. In 1879, another stone tablet by the same artist was added to the left with the likeness of [[Justus Hiddes Halbertsma]].Koopmans, p. 309.Twerda, p. 299. Furthermore, in 1903 the Selskip ordered a [[statue]] of Eeltsje Halbertsma to be made and placed on Parkstrjitte ("Park Street") in Grou,Twerda, p. 298. consisting of a [[bust (sculpture)|bust]] on a more than man-high [[limestone]] [[column]] resting on a [[pedestal]] of [[granite]], made by Johan Schröder.De Vries, p. 98. The inscription reads: "TO DR EELTSJE HIDDES HALBERTSMA", with on the back of the column: "''Ljeaf bliuwe ús Fryske tael en liet.''" ("Beloved to us remain the Western Frisian language and its songs.")De Vries, p. 98. ==Bibliography== * 1821 – ''Soe Ik Net in Wurdsje Sizze'' ("Would I Not Say a Few Words"; poem) * 1822 – ''Hjir Is in Krintebôle'' ("Take This Currant Bread"; rhyme) * 1822 – ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' ("Gabe Tailor's Rag Basket"; collection of poetry and short stories, with [[Justus Hiddes Halbertsma]]) * 1823 – ''Nijjierswinsk oan in Ald Boargemaster'' ("New Year's Wish to a Former Mayor"; poem) * 1823 – ''Us Gysbertomme'' ("Our Uncle Gysbert"; poem about [[Gysbert Japiks]]) * 1829 – ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' (collection of poetry and short stories, with Justus Hiddes Halbertsma; expanded version) * 1830 – ''Yn de Dollejoarum Rinne'' ("Walking Deep in Thought"; short story) * 1831 – ''Foeke Skutter en Hospes' Tryn'' ("Citizen Soldier Foeke and Tryn the Innkeeper's Wife"; short story with a poem) * 1833 – ''Fêsteljûnpraatsje'' ("Shrove Tuesday's Talk"; [[dialogue]]) * 1833 – ''Ybel en Jelke, of: De Boask op it Iis'' (Ybel and Jelke, or: The Marriage on the Ice"; poem) * 1834 – ''De Lapekoer fan Gabe Skroar'' (collection of poetry and short stories, with Justus Hiddes Halbertsma; further expanded version) * 1835 – ''De Skearwinkel fan Joutebaas'' ("Boss Joute's Barbershop"; frame-story with several poems and short stories, with Justus Hiddes Halbertsma en [[Tsjalling Hiddes Halbertsma]]) * 1836 – ''De Noarger Rún oan Gabe Skroar'' ("The [[Norg]] Gelding to Gabe Tailor"; short story with a poem) * 1836 – ''De Treemter fan it Sint-Anthonygasthûs'' ("The Conversation Room of St. Anthony's Hospital"; short story) * 1837 – ''Eölus, Grewa fan Stoarm en Onwaar'' ("Aeolus, Lord of Storm and Thunder"; poetry and short story collection, with Justus Hiddes Halbertsma) * 1837 – ''Op it Doktor-wurden fan Myn Miich K.T. {{Refimprove|date=July 2015}} The '''European quadriga''' is the designation of the quadrumvirate representing the [[European Union]] in its foreign relations, in particular with [[Greece]] concerning its common foreign and security policy (CFSP). The formerly known [[European troika|Troika]] is now being renamed as "Quadriga", to note the inclusion of the [[European Stability Mechanism]] (ESM) in the talks specially with the new Greek project of a third aid program amounting to 86 billion euros due to start on 20 August 2015.
"Quadriga" is the name inspired by Commission President, [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] for the new Greek project and creditors have now added the ESM to their collective and rebranded themselves "The Quadriga."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2015-07-27/goodbye-troika-germany-rides-its-greek-colony-quadriga |title=Goodbye Troika: Germany Rides Into Its Greek Colony On The "Quadriga" |publisher=Zero Hedge |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref>
While talking about the quadriga (especially in the media) one refers to a decision group formed by the [[European Commission]] (EC), the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB), the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) and the newly added European Stability Mechanism (ESM).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://global.handelsblatt.com/edition/228/ressort/politics/article/from-troika-to-quadriga From Troika to Quadriga]
[[Category:European Union economic policy]] [[Category:Political terminology]]

{{about||integrated circuit diagrams|Floorplan (microelectronics)|the financial term|Retail floorplan}}
[[Image:Sample Floorplan.jpg|thumb|320px|Sample floor plan for a [[single-family detached home]]]]{{views}} In [[architecture]] and [[building engineering]], a '''floor plan''' is a drawing to [[Scale (ratio)|scale]], showing a view from above, of the relationships between rooms, spaces, traffic patterns, and other physical features at one level of a structure.
Dimensions are usually drawn between the walls to specify room sizes and wall lengths. Floor plans may also include details of fixtures like sinks, water heaters, furnaces, etc. Floor plans may include notes for construction to specify finishes, construction methods, or symbols for electrical items.
It is also called a ''[[Plan view|plan]]'' which is a measured plane typically projected at the floor height of {{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}}, as opposed to an ''[[Elevation (view)|elevation]]'' which is a measured plane projected from the side of a building, along its height, or a section or ''[[cross section (geometry)|cross section]]'' where a [[building]] is cut along an axis to reveal the interior structure.
==Overview== Similar to a [[map]] the orientation of the view is downward from above, but unlike a conventional [[map]], a plan is drawn at a particular vertical position (commonly at about 4 feet above the floor). Objects below this level are seen, objects at this level are shown 'cut' in plan-section, and objects above this vertical position within the structure are omitted or shown dashed. [[Plan view]] or planform is defined as a vertical [[orthographic projection]] of an object on a horizontal plane, like a map.
The term may be used in general to describe any drawing showing the physical layout of objects. For example, it may denote the arrangement of the displayed objects at an [[Art exhibition|exhibition]], or the arrangement of exhibitor booths at a [[Convention (meeting)|convention]]. Drawings are now reproduced using [[Plotter|plotters]] and large format [[xerographic]] copiers.
A ''reflected ceiling plan'' (RCP) shows a view of the room as if looking from above, through the ceiling, at a mirror installed one foot below the ceiling level, which shows the ''reflected'' image of the ceiling above. This convention maintains the same orientation of the floor and ceilings plans - looking down from above. RCPs are used by designers and architects to demonstrate lighting, visible mechanical features, and ceiling forms as part of the documents provided for construction.
==Floor plan topics==
===Building blocks=== [[File:Architectural plan, door1.svg|alt=A schematic drawing of an open door, seen from the top, with a curved line that shows a quarter-circle space on the floor that the door travels over when it opens|thumb|Floor plans use standard symbols to indicate features such as doors. This symbol shows the location of the door in a wall and which way the door opens.]]
A floor plan is not a top view or [[birds eye view]]. It is a measured drawing to scale of the layout of a floor in a building. A ''top view'' or ''bird's eye view'' does not show an orthogonally projected plane cut at the typical four foot height above the floor level. A floor plan could show:<ref>[http://www.sanjoseca.gov/planning/counter/planning_sanjose/Planning_in_San_Jose_pt3.pdf Site Plans, Elevations and Floor Plans] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607213549/http://www.sanjoseca.gov/planning/counter/planning_sanjose/Planning_in_San_Jose_pt3.pdf |date=2010-06-07 }} ''A Community Guide San Jose''. Accessed 11 February 2009.</ref> * Interior walls and hallways * Restrooms * Windows and doors * Appliances such as stoves, refrigerators, water heater etc. * Interior features such as fireplaces, saunas and whirlpools * The use of all rooms
===Plan view=== A [[plan view]] is an [[orthographic projection]] of a three-dimensional object from the position of a horizontal plane through the object. In other words, a plan is a [[Cross section (geometry)|section]] viewed from the top. In such views, the portion of the object above the plane (section) is omitted to reveal what lies beyond. In the case of a floor plan, the roof and upper portion of the walls may typically be omitted. Whenever an interior design project is being approached, a floor plan is the typical starting point for any further design considerations and decisions.
Roof plans are orthographic projections, but they are not sections as their viewing plane is outside of the object.
A plan is a common method of depicting the internal arrangement of a three-dimensional object in two dimensions. It is often used in [[technical drawing]] and is traditionally crosshatched. The style of crosshatching indicates the type of material the section passes through.
===3D floor plans=== A [[3D floor plan]] can be defined as a virtual model of a building floor plan. It is often used to better convey architectural plans to individuals not familiar with floor plans. Despite the purpose of floor plans originally being to depict 3D layouts in a 2D manner, technological expansion has made rendering 3D models much more cost effective. 3D plans show a better depth of image and are often complimented by 3D furniture in the room. This allows a greater appreciation of scale than with traditional 2D floor plans.
==Examples== <gallery widths="500px" heights="250px" perrow="6"> Image:Carvansara plan.gif|A sample floor plan of a [[Caravanserai]]. File:Office plane.svg|An office plan. File:Frankfurt Am Main-Leonhardskirche-Grundriss.png|Church floor plan, [[St. Leonhard, Frankfurt]], transformed from Romanesque to Gothic File:Társasház alaprajza (részlet).jpg|Registration floor plan of a condo (detail) </gallery>
==See also== * [[3D printing]] * [[3D scanner]] * [[Architect's scale]] * [[Architectural drawing]] * [[Comparison of computer-aided design editors|List of floor plan software]] * [[House]] * [[House plan]] * [[Indoor positioning system]] (IPS) * [[Room number]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category-inline|floor plans}}
